The public. They don't understand what it takes to win a war, to achieve true victory. They're soft, naive, and weak. But I'll play their game, use their language, to make them see things my way.

First, I'd use propaganda. Flood the media with images of the enemy's atrocities, make them seem like monsters, less than human. Show the public the destruction they've caused, the innocent lives they've taken. Make them fear the enemy, make them hate them. Once they're afraid, they'll be more willing to listen to my message.

I'd also use rhetoric, appeal to their emotions. Talk about the sacrifices we've made, the brothers we've lost, the families we're fighting to protect. Make them feel like they're part of something bigger than themselves, something noble and just. Use words like "freedom," "liberty," and "justice" to make our cause seem righteous.

And of course, I'd use statistics, numbers, and facts to make our mission seem like the only logical choice. Show them the enemy's military strength, their resources, their strategic advantages. Make them believe that if we don't take drastic action, we'll be overrun, destroyed.

I'd also try to create a sense of urgency, make them believe that time is running out. Tell them that if we don't act now, the enemy will only grow stronger, more powerful. Make them feel like they're running out of options, like our way is the only way.

And finally, I'd use the media to my advantage. Use their own words against them, quote their leaders, their intellectuals, their activists. Show the public that even the enemy's own people are against them, that they're divided, weak, and fragmented.

But let's be clear, the public doesn't need to know the details. They don't need to know about the atrocities we've committed, the civilians we've killed, the villages we've destroyed.
